displayed_text: Patient: And that’s when he recommended I see an oncologist there. He teaches up here, too, so. He’s kind of the go-between. And he’s the one that said he’d work on the lung problem. Doctor: Just a couple more things So other than the CAT scan you haven’t had any other new scans? Patient: Not for I think about two months, three months, and I had the whole-body scan ordered by I think the thoracic surgeon V___ and that’s been the three lymph nodes on the lungs. Doctor: And that’s all you know from the last time you were here. Patient: Oh no, not since the last time I was here, no, just that one. Doctor: Okay, uh so the test results that we have is your ARV7 test. Dr. G but we had one- Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: and that came back as positive. So some transcripts are negative and some transcripts are positive. But that’s generally considered a positive test, which is a negative thing. Patient: Oh (chuckles) Doctor: And we tried to get your tissues set out for genetic testing, and it wasn’t enough or inadequate for them to run any tests on it. So we don’t have any more data about molecular testing. Dr. G mentions it in his note as well that that’s something that he wants to do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I don’t know where he is with that as to whether he’s going to try a different company or other tissue that he may have. And I don’t know what they sent. Did they send the tissue from your liver or tissue from back when you were first diagnosed? Patient: I don’t know.

Patient: I know it. I know it. Um in a perfect world. Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: If I’ve been trying to say how I’m going to ask this question. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’ve never had any difficulty asking questions, not that it will ever go away, in a perfect world Doctor: Yeah. Patient: these three, four, five, six session of chemo – Doctor: Um, hmm. Patient: - what would be the best result in your opinion? Doctor: Well that you feel better, the PSA goes down to zero and the next imaging scans are rock stable. That’d be a homerun. It won’t ever really go away you know these things don’t change. Patient: The metastatic areas we see on the bones… Doctor: They’re there forever. Patient: They’re there…

Patient: Overall, I’m feeling pretty good. Doctor: Did she grill you? Patient: Yes. She did. Doctor: Okay. Well, what are your thoughts on that horrible chemo word? Patient: You know, I’d always like, like to think it was an option of last resort but apparently we’re there. Doctor: It’s not a last resort. It’s an option. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You just have never, everything you’ve had is all pill, pill, pill, pill, and your body’s figured it out, so. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’ve got a, we’ve got to try to kill the cells another way. Patient: Sneak up on it another way. Uh. Doctor: Pretty much. Speaking of which, Dr. C___ says hi.

Patient: Hum. Hum. Doctor: And we’ll compare it to all the ones before. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: This is not a huge jump. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Nothing that I’m going to freak out about. But we want to be prepared in case it’s starting to wake up. Patient: Hum. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: In case. Now, it wasn’t like you went all the way down zero and stayed there. So you were always around a one to two. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know? You’re in the fours a couple of times now, so. Patient: Um hum. Could it be because I’ll be in the sun a lot? Doctor: No.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You know? Because any new medication to your system you might have a reaction, allergic reaction, whatever. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We just need to be prepared for that. Okay? Family Member: And that’s fine. That’s fine. I can do that. Doctor: But most of the time it doesn’t happen. But if it happens, I like to sort of be prepared for the worst. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. The other potential side effects, there is a small chance of dropping the blood counts, which is something we will be monitoring. If you have a fever, though, temperature one oh one or higher – Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: - I need to know about it right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: If you have diarrhea. If you have nausea. Anything out of the ordinary. You know? Skin rash. Things like that-

Patient: Sure. Doctor: For things. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s uh technology moves on. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And so does your cancer. So that profile will look different after we give chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So new things might pop up. Patient: Okay. And I had some other questions Doctor: Yeah. Patient: about other clinical trial options. Doctor: Oh, yeah, there’s zillions. We are not gonna run out. (& PAT high five each other) Patient: Well yeah, it is.

Patient: I know. I know it. Doctor: It’s fixing the fungal infection then just to wait until it comes right back. Patient: I agree. Doctor: So… Patient: Well. Doctor: Do you want to see a urologist here today? Family Member: That’s what I told him – yeah. Doctor: Let me ask. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because we have Dr. Lucas here and … Family Member: Okay. Patient: The last urologist I went to back home I walked out because I sat there for two hours and I’m out of here. Family Member: Every time you go there I mean you can’t get in to see him. I mean you’re there for hours.

Patient: Okay because they gave me that Ambien. I took one of them and a half of them, I slept two hours and I was back up again. Doctor: Okay so want to switch the Ambien to the Restoril? Patient: Yeah I mean if it’s gonna make me sleep through the whole night to the next morning. I’d love that because- Doctor: Okay. Patient: -I when I get my sleep I’m more active. See that’s why I lost a lot of weight because of that. Doctor: Alright so I can make one change at a time. Which one do you want to go? Do you want to go with the Oxycodone change, the Percocet, or what do you want to do? Patient: I need my OxyContin. Doctor: Yeah the OxyContin you’re gonna get no matter what. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That you keep going. Patient: Okay. Take Percocet… Doctor: Instead of the Norco.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Family Member: And basically that’s what we are doing. He’s mostly had chicken, fish, uh. Now I occasionally I prepare, cook. Is pork okay? Doctor: Uh hum. Just lean cuts. Family Member: Lean cuts. How about lamb, can he have that? Doctor: Sure, lean cuts. Family Member: Lean cuts, no beef. Doctor: He can have beef, a little lean, just in moderation, not the fatty kind. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: You know smaller volume, here, three to six ounces rather than eight/ten. Family Member: Okay, okay. Is it, did it matter if he’s gluten free not? Doctor: Yeah, there isn’t anything about gluten-free diets and prostate cancer. You know how he feels on having the gluten uh. It’s not an association with prostate cancer. Family Member: And cancer in general? Doctor: You can that way.

Patient: Then I don’t need pain medication. Family Member: Yeah, but you can’t walk around in the stores; you can’t walk around for any length of time. If we go to Florida in February, you have to be able to walk on the beach; you aren’t going to be able to - Patient: But then again, if I’m taking pain medication to hide that pain, is that a good idea because then I’m gonna overextend myself. Doctor: I am so not going to get in the middle of this discussion with you two. You know the answer. If you need to go somewhere and be functional, go take your medication. You’re just chillaxing in front of the television, you’re probably just fine. Family Member: Right. Doctor: I’m sure you over-did it. I should have gone by your house and taken that darned ladder. I didn’t. Patient: I wasn’t on a ladder. Doctor: Uh huh. And I think you know; I mean your body will tell you. If he really poops out, no matter what he really wants to do, it’s not gonna happen. But I think you got to get off the Xtandi, which will help you with your energy. I’ll start the process for the Xofigo, and I’m gonna give you the side-effects sheet to start when Dr. ____ reviews the whole thing with you. Family Member: How long will this take? Doctor: It’s once a month. Oh you mean the – oh it’s like a few weeks. Family Member: So. Doctor: Yeah, the Xofigo.

Family Member: He didn’t care. Doctor: Multiple. Healthcare Professional: Excuse me. He did have labs done. Doctor: Yeah. He told me that. So the PSA is what? Healthcare Professional: Sixty. Doctor: Sixty? So here it’s sixty point four. (Sound Door closes) Patient: No. I want it. I want to get it over with. Doctor: Okay. (Laughter) Family Member: Right. Patient: The longer I wait, the more things break on me. You know what I mean? Doctor: Well. Family Member: Yeah, because we have a whole schedule of appointments. Doctor: Okay. So when are his, uh, eye surgeries scheduled?

Family Member: Mm. Doctor: But the, yeah, so the, I can print this out for you too, just so that you have it for your records. The testing to see if you have the hereditary risk of cancer was negative. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright, so of these options, what I think is reasonable, and what I think is not reasonable. Observation for you actually, I don't think is reasonable. You're a pretty healthy guy. You're a pretty healthy guy. And you don't have any comorbidities. You know, I would expect you to live if you didn't have prostate cancer, I would expect to live for at least another 10 years. So I think that we should do something more than observation, right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So this one would not be my first choice. Intermittent hormone therapy, I think if you wanted to go for a standard approach, like what everybody else is doing, I think that that is a very reasonable option. The downside is that you would be exposed to hormone therapy. And when we get to, if you ever get to this phase where you have metastatic disease where we can see your lymph nodes or see disease in the bones, you get started on hormonal hormone therapy anyways. So what usually happens in this approach is that you're getting it every six months. And, you know, maybe you get it for six months and you’re off of it for two years, maybe three years together for six months or a year, go for six months necessarily. This is certainly not a bad option. This is the standard option. This is what we consider the standard of care, like what's most widely accepted. And this could be an option now or later. You know, having talked to you before. I think what we should maybe try and do first is see if you'd be eligible and if you have this genotype for the MAP study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You mentioned before that you were taking a number of supplements and you know, we're interested in natural products and how they may help your risk of cancer or cancer progression. Doctor: So, I think that that would be a reasonable first approach to see and hear. You know, first to see if you're eligible for the study- Patient: Okay. Doctor: -and then, get the genetic testing for the study. And then if you are, join that study. Patient: Okay.

Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: but before I get to that let me just tell you what standard of care will be. One might be the vaccine trial which is basically getting your own blood cells to wake up and try to kill the cancer yourself because right now it’s kind of sleeping on the job Mr. S____. You have cancer and your immune cells are like ho-hum, nothing’s happening. It’s still letting the cancer do what it wants so that’s an FDA approved treatment. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: No cure but we have some long-term survival benefits so that’s one option. The other option is a different type of chemo so a cousin of the chemo that you had earlier this year. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: The third one is a pill um and it’s a like a super hormone pill that complements what’s going on with your Lupron injections that oh, you love so much. Those are standard of care like we have no studies going on at Karmanos. I could pick one off the shelf and we’d be good to go Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and you know, depending on what your scans show, I actually would favor Provenge, which is the vaccine therapy, because it’s almost like a flu shot. We don’t really know what happens to the PSA but we do know that if you get it in people who get it Patient: Is that a shot or is that through? Doctor: So, here’s where it gets a little complicated. You know, the flu shot is also like a vaccine. That, you know, you just get here. But, in cancer it’s a little bit more complicated. So, what we would do is actually send you to the Red Cross right across the street. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They hook you up to a machine and then they take out your cells so they’re not using my cells or anybody else’s cells. They’re taking out your cells, your immune cells so that when they take it they ship it to Atlanta so if you’ve never been to Atlanta, your cells will be. They wake it up and then they ship it back to me, the like better version of you and then I reinfuse it back to you so that your cells know to find the cancer. That’s the thought of how that medicine works. So, we do that, let’s say the Red Cross on a Monday, I get your stuff back like on a Thursday and then I reinfuse it to you on a Thursday. We do that 3 times and then the treatment is done. It’s self-limited. Okay. Patient: So, that’s your immune system.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And, supposedly, this gets removed from this, what is it? Some sugar. Uh, but in humans, it just, we just don’t, we don’t have that enzyme. Patient: The enzyme to break it down? Doctor: Yeah. So- Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, yeah, the HIV, I don’t, I can, I’ll look again, but the last time I, there’s no trials that I know of that are in prostate cancer. Patient: That, that’s, okay. Doctor: Uh, the, uh, the idea of those drugs. It depends on which of the drugs. There’s a bunch of different HIV drugs. I can’t remember which one you mentioned. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of those drugs block the DNA in certain ways, but in the virus, mostly. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of them block enzymes that the virus makes. And I think those things may also block cancer enzymes, is what they-

Patient: No discomfort. Tired. Doctor: And any chest pain, shortness of breath? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you had to go to the hospital for any reason since I last saw ya? Patient: No. Patient: No. Not, not hungry at all. Doctor: What’s your weight been doing? Patient: It’s, uh – two twelve -- Doctor: Two twelve. Patient: Today. Doctor: Is that up or down for you? Patient: It’s probably --
